body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @philipwalton 

- Adds ability to load modules in workbox-sw
    - Three options around this:
        1. `modulePathPrefix` allows you to customise the path workbox-sw uses to import modules.
        2. `modulePathCb` allows a developers to completely control where a module is looked up.
        3. `disableModuleImports` force the library to only use globals and throw an error otherwise.
- Adds new line after description lint rule
- Allows deploying the v3 branch to the CDN regardless of whether it's already deployed or not (Will be helpful for testing)

Biggest question I have with this PR is around how we manage versions on CDN vs NPM.

At the moment we version modules separately so we avoid needless update churn. The CDN updates whenever a new git tag is released.

In this PR, I'm assuming the version in the `lerna.json` file is a safe way to get the latest tag being pushed to the CDN and using that inject the version to use into workbox-sw. (See VERSION = `WORKBOX_VERSION_TAG`). I'm not sure if this will be enough when publishing with lerna (i.e. will it bump this version before cutting the release or is it done after).

body:
Solves point 3 of #814

I know this PR looks like a complete change but thats because I've removed the iffe and indented each line.

Changes are:
- Removed iife
- Moved imports to before where the ENV is changed - this ensures that the import is using the correct NODE_ENV
- Cleared the require cache (workbox-core doesn't expose the assert library in prod and if you require it once with prod, it'll never expose assert).
- Changed the await wrapping to import module and then reference default.

This will likely changed based on discussion in #814 but I really don't want this pattern to be continued, hence this PR.

R: @addyosmani @gauntface @philipwalton @prateekbh 
CC: @goldhand 

Apologies for the size of this PR, but there's a lot of code needed to get `workbox-build` happy in v3.

Some things to keep in mind:
- Functionality-wise, this is in keeping with what `workbox-build` supported in v2. There are plans to update the interfaces/clean some things up, but I wanted to get a mostly-identical version migrated first to unblock #808.
  - One exception: All of the runtime code, and some of the tests, have moved from Promises to `async`/`await` (transpiled with Babel to maintain Node 4 support).
  - Another exception: The `dynamicUrlToDependencies` and `staticFileGlobs` options printed warnings when used in v2, and I've fully deprecated them in v3.
- This is the first package that targets the Node environment, rather than the Browser. I had to make some hacks to the testing setup, and some worse hacks to the build process, to get that to work with the way things are set up in v3. Longer-term, it might make sense to revisit the v3 build setup to allow individual packages to specify their own build process, like we allowed in v2.
- I had to move over a bunch of test/infrastructure code from v2 to get the `workbox-build` tests working. For the most part, I stuck them in `infra/`, and that's already getting a bit messy.

body:
## tl;dr

This is a prototype for the `workbox-webpack-plugin` for the v3 release. This address some of the points mentioned in #696 . Not all of the configuration from the existing `workbox-webpack-plugin` has been migrated (or configuration from `sw-precache-webpack-plugin`) but that was not the focus of this prototype. The goal of this prototype is to solve for some of the difficult webpack-specific features, including:
* Supporting `webpack-dev-middleware` by generating the `service-worker`, `file-manifest`, and built version of `workbox-sw` **in-memory** (rather than writing to disk). I've tested this and confirmed support for `webpack-dev-middleware` / `webpack-dev-server`.
* Filtering files by chunk names.
* Copying`workbox-sw` to the webpack assets.


⚠️ *I haven't updated the tests yet, I was manually testing by using an ejected create-react-app instance that imports the plugin using a relative file path.*
⚠️  *One issue (mentioned in the [blocks](#blocks) section below, was that I wasn't able to import the `workbox-sw` package into the `workbox-webpack-plugin` package. See details in the blocks section for my work-around.*


# V3 Changes to workbox-webpack-plugin

Following are details of the design, proposed api changes, and issues I am having that I am hoping someone will provide help with.

## Requirements
*from the #725 v3 tracker*
* [ ] Switch to CDN by default
* [ ] Include option to not use CDN and copy files over
* [ ] Update API to implement v3 proposal
* [x] Use compilation assets to generate a manifest (instead of globPatterns)
* [x] Allow user to specify chunks to be used when creating the manifest
* [x] Generate service worker “in-memory” and make webpack responsible for writing to file system
* [ ] Support sw-precache config in workbox-webpack plugin (runtime-caching? drop staticFileIgnores in favor of “chunks” api)

Im not clear what the *CDN* related tasks are.

## Re-architecture
The objective is to provide a seamless experience for developers who want to use workbox in projects that rely on webpack for building.
Webpack contains information about the build files and versions of those files that workbox can leverage to manage service worker caching.

### Tenets
* Try to use as many existing workbox utilities to generate the service worker through webpack without compromising the developer experience.
* Ensure all required service worker assets are emitted through webpack so workbox can be used with `webpack-dev-middleware`.

### Design
* In most webpack build systems, webpack is aware of all the built static assets as well as if there are changes in those assets. Were going to use webpack to generate a file manifest that `workbox-sw` can use for precaching instead of using `workbox-build/generate-file-manifest`.
* Filter manifest files to include / exclude files by chunk name. This is provided by the `config.chunks` and `config.excludeChunks`, respectively (mirroring the `html-webpack-plugin` api).
* If we need to use the `compiler.inputFileSystem._readFile` method instead of `fs.readFile`, use the `workbox-webpack-plugin/utils/read-file.js` method that is configured to use `compiler.inputFileSystem._readFile` during the **run** phase of the webpack compilation lifecycle.
* `workbox-build` will copy a built `workbox-sw` into the service worker output path. This needs to done through the webpack. During the **make** phase of the webpack compilation, we use `workbox-webpack-plugin/utils/copy-workbox-sw` to add a built version of `workbox-sw` to the webpack compilation assets array. We can't use the `workbox-build/utils/copy-workbox-sw` utility because it writes to the filesystem.
* The version of `workbox-sw` is included in it's filename so we need that information to import it in the generated service worker. `workbox-webpack-plugin/utils/copy-workbox-sw` also returns the `workbox-sw` filename so we can pass it to `workbox-webpack-plugin/generate-webpack-sw`.
* During the **emit** phase of the webpack lifecycle, we:
  1. Get the manifest entries
  1. Use the entries to generate a file-manifest
  1. Generate a service worker with the file-manifest name and `workbox-sw` filename or copy a service worker from the `config.swSrc` then prepend it with the required `importScripts(workbox-sw.js, file-manifest.js)`.
  1. Add both the file-manifest and the service-worker to the webpack assets.

#### Todo
* I'm not passing any configuration into `sw-build.generateSW` as we would need to. This is because of the pattern where utilities *write* to the file system. If we don't change the utilities, one way to fix this would be to copy the *template populate* logic from `sw-build/generate-sw`. Ideally we could abstract the populating logic from `generate-sw` into a util that does not write to the file system.
* Honor `swDest` incase users want to separate the service worker from build directory.
* There may be cases where assets are not emitted by webpack (the `public/` dir in create-react-app, for example). We should provide a way to "merge" `workbox-build/get-file-manifest-entries` with `workbox-webpack-plugin/get-webpack-manifest-entries`.  `workbox-build/get-file-manifest-entries` supports globPatterns for finding assets, and can be used to generate manifest entries for files that do not go through webpack. Could be a simple `Object.assign(webpackEntries, workboxEntries)`.
* Supoort `sw-precache-webpack-plugin` configurations.
* Fix tests (once the `sw-build/generate-sw`) item is resolved.

### API changes
These are just proposals, we can stay within the exisiting API but I wanted to collect feedback for these changes.

* Running `workbox-build` in `injectManifest` mode will not copy `workbox-sw` over but this is a known pain point for developers. Instead, copy the `workbox-sw` over then prefix the existing service worker with an `importScripts(workbox-sw-V.xxx.js)` line.
* Always generate a file manifest (do not support `injectManifest` mode). We can effectively "inject" the manifest by taking a `config.manifestVarName` parameter that will be used in the `file-manifest.js` template: (`self.${config.manifestVarName} = ${fileManifest}`) and prepend an `importScripts(${manifestFileName})` line to the existing service worker.

### Blocks
* I wasn't able to import the `workbox-sw` package into the `workbox-webpack-plugin` package (in the `workbox-webpack-plugin/utils/copy-workbox-sw` utility). I kept getting a "module not found error" when I manually tested using the create-react-app approach). My work around was to add the `copy-workbox-sw` to the `workbox-build` package (that I was able to import) and manually test using that.
* A lot of the utilities use `fs` to read lodash templates. There may be problems using `fs` in webpack plugins (I removed it from `sw-precache-webpack-plugin` and @TheLarkInn mentioned using `compiler.outputFileSystem` instead).
* Utilities often *populate* then *write* the populated template to the filesystem. I'm having to duplicate and isolate the *populate* logic and am referencing the lodash templates across modules.

body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @philipwalton 

This is one possible adaption of the current requestWrapper stuff we have in workbox-runtime-caching at the moment.

# Differences

There are a few major differences between this PR vs current requestWrapper. Below is list of differences and explanations:

- Dropped waitOnCache and cacheKey
- Seperated requestWrapper into fetchWrapper and cacheWrapper.
    - These two changes were hand in hand. waitOnCache and cacheKey were only used by precaching and removing them simplified the overall code for the *Wrapper modules. Seperation was needed to enable precaching to perform these features.
- Removed the restriction of single plugins to manipulate values.
    - Reading through the current requestWrapper code I wasn't sure why some plugin methods could only have callback vs others. I've added some tests to show how multiple plugins will play together and didn't find anything too concerning in terms of a developer understanding. But I may be missing scenarios.
- fetchWrapper and cacheWrapper export static functions
- Plugins are looped through and relevant functions are called if they exist. Previously a map was generated in the RequestWrapper constructor. Will be inefficient if a large number of plugins were used.

# Discussion Points

- API doesn't allow for a global set of plugins at the moment, but we could add a method to workbox-core allowing a developer to set plugins which could be called before or after the specific function plugins.

```javascript
import core from 'workbox-core';
core.setGlobalPlugins([
    ......
]);
```

I still need to account for where cache names come from where they are defined, but again the PR was getting pretty big, so stopped from progressing further. Will work on this in the next PR.

body:
In the original proposal for publishing files, there was an awkward set up where file names with underscore are auto-excluded from browser builds and the browser builds would be generated from an auto-generated file exporting all files. I wasn't happy with this and generally no one liked the "internal" name.

After digging a little more into Rollup (and I'm still learning) it seems like we could still offer the same build size wins to developers with just normal named exports on the main export (i.e. what we are doing today).

We would still need to export classes / objects from one module to another even if we wanted them to be private (i.e. logger / assertions). Instead of "internal" I've just moved to an `_private.mjs` file that has multiple exports under `_private` variable.

body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani 

This was a bit of an exploration PR, so sorry for some of the sweeping changes.

I started to dig into few different things:

1. How we'd publish this to NPM such that modules would have a sane import without making our packages/<module name> feel cluttered
2. Not ship the entry point for rollup
3. Add a custom class for errors that will handle the code -> message conversion.

On dev, the messages.mjs class will be included (i.e. the messages associated with the code, however on prod, only the error code and details is displayed and the messages.mjs is not included in the final bundle.

Things that would be good for feedback:
1. Should we use .mjs? Seems like it'll be the future spec, but does require us to explicitly use .mjs on the imports.
2. Should the tests live in top level  `test` or in the packages? I moved them out since having the module source code in the root (which will be need to support `import ClassName from 'module/ClassName'`) was getting messy with test directory.
3. Should we do something to make it clear to developers where files aren't intended for public use? I.e. I've moved some classes on workbox-core to "INTERNAL", the idea being that this should make it obvious that it's not meant for public use but doesn't prevent developers from using it.

R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @gauntface

Here it comes . . . . . . I promise I'm not crazy :-/

![giphy 4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139760/29193774-8cf9f244-7ddb-11e7-98f3-c9a9ea63a1f0.gif)

This is a tool that pulls out property names and function names. The idea being that if we have a tonne of variables being used that are public or not marked as private, the minifier is unable to rename it. This means the end file size will be larger than it needs to be.

I have no idea if this will be used going forward or not. But after manually going through some of the workbox-core code's and refactor slightly to shave off bundle size ~850 bytes to ~ 750 bytes. Moving forward with much larger code, I suspect that this **might** be useful.

I'd like to keep this in the infra directory just in case it does proof handy and I've added a comment to remove if it doesn't get used / isn't useful.

It filters out words which are only reference once in the source (i.e. public functions / properties) and will exclude single character variables names from the output. Currently we have all variables stripped apart from our namespace which occurs several times to initialize the namespace.

```shell
$ gulp build && node ./infra/tools/analyse-properties.js
```

R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #709, fixes #533 

`await` is nice in that it doesn't require the expression to actually evaluate to a promise So both `await Promise.resolve(true)` and `await true` are both valid.

Because of this, I just had to change the code that calls the lifecycle methods to consistently use `await`, and the existing plugins that don't need to do anything asynchronous don't have to be updated.

This opens the doors for new plugins that weren't previously able to return promises, like the Range request helper in #710.

I took the opportunity to add in formal JSDoc for the lifecycle methods, via `@callback`, since that was a longstanding issue.

body: R: @kaycebasques @addyosmani @gauntface Fixes #695 This normalizes the configuration options used throughout the various `workbox-build` methods, and puts all of them in a standard JSDoc interface. I also took the opportunity to add in some previously undocumented options, correct errors in the descriptions and defaults, and update the samples for `workbox-build`. There are some options that only apply to `generateSW()` or `injectManifest()`, and I took the tact of leaving those in the main list of options, but specifically calling out the fact that they need to be used with one method of the other. The display of the rendered JSDoc, including whether the parameter is optional and its default value is... not amazing. I think we have a larger issue of getting nicer JSDoc output, and for the purposes of this PR, the raw JSDoc should be valid and (hopefully) accurate.

body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @gauntface

This adds a browser bundle build step.

Currently builds to `<package>/build/browser-bundles/<package name>.<dev|production>.js` The reasoning for this is that `build/` could be where we put our ES2015 module code (i.e. dump files that we want to be referenced as `import '<package name>/<classname or path to file>'`

Minifier has been switched to uglify-es, this is so that we can minify private variables, which for the small amount of code got use from ~900B down to ~750B. I'm running the bundled tests through the minifier as well just to try and account for the fact that the source in our library code will ultimately be different and hopefully catch us out but this does make me nervous if we rely on the bundled tests too much.

Build process for packages is using lerna from start to finish. `gulp build` will simply run `lerna bootstrap` behind the scenes. Lerna should figure out the dependencies between modules and will then run `npm run prepublish` on each package. Each package should then run `gulp build-packages --package <package name>`. This should mean are working *with* lerna rather than against / next to it.

PR-Bot should now show the built file sizes in this PR.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface 
CC: @HenrikJoreteg @liuruoran88

This fixes #714 by explicitly changing the method call inside of `WorkboxSW` to indicate that for the internal `CacheOnly` handler use for precached requests, `cacheId` shouldn't be prepended when determining the corresponding cache name.

I decided to go with that approach rather than making a chance in the `RequestWrapper` constructor that checked to see if `cacheId` was already present in the `cacheName`, since you could theoretically imagine calling

```js
new RequestWrapper({
  cacheName: 'my-prefix',
  cacheId: 'my-prefix',
}});
```

In that situation, the user would expect the effective cache name to be `'my-prefix-my-prefix'`, and we'd want to still allow that.

body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @gauntface @philipwalton 

This is a PR start to build up for V3 so please hammer on this for anything you see and don't like / disagree with.

Notes in terms of changes...........

## Eslint

Been slightly more strict on where console is used - this is solely to force the use of a log helper which can add prefixs and colors to helper figure out where logs are coming from in build process and tests.

I moved us off of the gulp-eslint plugin as it couldnt be configured to use our gitignore (i.e. we'd have to duplicate ignores in eslintignore or gulp.src). I checked that we fail the build if there is a lint problem.

## Testing

To enable @philipwalton's use case of having access to raw classes I plan on tweaking his approach of creating bundle files where our build process will look for files under `test/bundle/node/`, `test/bundle/browser/` and `test/bundle/sw/` this will result in a built bundle consisting of all JS files under this directory and the test runner (which I will add in at a later stage) will basically add scripts from `browser/`, `node/` and `sw/` along side the bundles in the respective environment.

**Please Comment On This**: The bundled tests are currently built and run with no NODE_ENV as well as a NODE_ENV of 'production'. The idea here being that if code changes it's behavior between environments, the tests can check the NODE_ENV and alter their behavior accordingly (i.e. ensure something exists or doesn't exist based on the NODE_ENV). I'm happy to strip this out so we only build one set of tests OR we can use flags to determine what node_env is run OR add multiple gulp tasks (one for prod one for dev). Just wondering what people would want / not want for this.

## Gulp

I've switched to gulp 4 so we can get better Promise support.

I took the idea of task runner and altered it into packageRunner, the idea is that it wraps functions that perform the gulp work into an array of functions, one item for each package it should run on (i.e. --project vs no --project). This works well with gulp.series and gulp.parallel - I added a big readme to the file to explain.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface @philipwalton 
CC: @jakearchibald @beaufortfrancois @paullewis as an FYI.

Fixes #372

This adds a new library that exposes a static method which takes in a `Request` with a `Range:` header and a `Response`, and returns a new `Response` with the partial content specified via the `Range:` header (or an error `Response` if the `Range:` was invalid).

It also adds in a new plugin class, meant to be used statically, that implements `RequestWrapper`'s `cacheWillMatch` lifecycle method, meaning it could be used easily from within `workbox-sw`.

This relies on reading and manipulating the entire source response body as a `Blob`, which is not as efficient as it would be if there were full Streams API support across all service worker implementation. It also forgoes a method that @paullewis seemed to have pioneered, in which a larger source `Response` is broken up into smaller individual `Response` chunks before it's cached, meaning that each individual body is smaller. I did not want this library to require that the original `Response` be cached in that specific chunked format, and the Streams API approach seems like the long-term solution anyway.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface
CC: @pbakaus

Fixes #691

This fixes a bug that would prevent a response used in a cache-first handler from properly triggering `maxAgeSeconds`-based expiration iff that response lacked a `Date:` header. A CORS-response without the `Date:` header specifically whitelisted via [`Access-Control-Expose-Headers`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Access_control_CORS#Access-Control-Expose-Headers) could trigger this scenario, as @pbakaus encountered.

This also changes the method signature of the `cacheWillMatch` lifecycle callback to be `async` (i.e. return a `Promise`), since we now want to wait for it to complete before returning a cached response to the client (to ensure that any expiration that's necessary gets performed). That should (arguably) be considered a breaking change, since `cacheWillMatch` is part of the public interface.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #626

This is based on the discussion from #626 + some follow-up meetings.

It adds support for a new `manifestTransforms` option to `workbox-build`, which takes one or more `ManifestTransform` functions as a parameter. This opens the door for doing post-processing of the manifest that was generated from `globPatterns` + `templatedUrls`.

I've reimplemented the existing `dontCacheBustUrlsMatching` and `modifyUrlPrefix` options so that they use the same manifest transformation pipeline.

I've made it so that its valid for an object `ManifestEntry` not to have a `revision` field, and that's treated the same way we treat a string `ManifestEntry`. I haven't removed support for using strings to represent manifest entries that lack `revision` fields, though we should revisit deprecating strings in favor of objects without `revision` fields in a future release.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface
CC: @jmtt89 @mikefowler

This is something of a straw-man PR, and feedback is welcome.

This partially addresses #385 and #636, but I'm not sure that I'd call it a "fix", so I'm inclined to leave them open.

Still, it should make it easier to accomplish what @jmtt89 was trying to do, by letting you use a method other than `'GET'` when calling `workboxSW.router.registerRoute()`.

It also provides an escape hatch granting greater flexibility by letting developers import and use `Route` objects created from the `workbox.routing` namespace, by relaxing the assertions to just check whether the object passed to `registerRoute()` has the properties that a `Route` should have, not necessarily whether it's a subclass of a specific definition of a `Route` object.

This PR doesn't attempt to add in a factory method for creating new `Route` objects exposed via`workboxSW.router`, although that's an idea that's been discussed in the past and might still be on the table.

R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani 

This is what I had in mind to manage errors in Workbox. It moves the error messages into a class which has a few nice features:

1. Errors will be displayed as 'WorkboxErrors' in the console.
1. Messages can be swapped out between dev and prod (hopefully reducing file size).
1. We can inline additional information in the message.
1. Add's consistency format of extra values

Major con is that is requires all messages to be accessible via this one WorkboxError class. We can organise the error-message-factory to pull in seperate files from packages or have it all in one file - not sure.

Let me know what you think.

body:
R: @gauntface 

The general logic is:
- If `--config-file` isn't given, then attempt to read a `./workbox-cli-config.js` file.
  - If that doesn't exist, then continue with the previous flow.
  - If it does exist, then continue with the previous flow.
- If `--config-file` is given, then attempt to read it (supporting both relative and absolute paths).
  - If that doesn't exist, then treat it as a fatal error.
  - If it does exist, then treat it the same way we were previously treating the default config.

This also adds in a logging statement letting the developer know which config file is being read from, as a general heads-up.

```
  --ignoreUrlParametersMatching [/^example/, /^other/]
  --navigateFallbackWhitelist [/^\/guide\//, /^\/lolz\//]
  --staticFileGlobs ['**/*.{html,js,css}']
  --modifyUrlPrefix {'/styles': '/static/styles','/page': '/pages/page'}
  --runtimeCaching [{urlPattern: /^https:\/\/example\.com\/api/,handler: 'cacheFirst'}]
  --dynamicUrlToDependencies { '/template/url1': ['page-1.html', 'index.html'], '/template/url2': ['page-2.html', 'index.html'],}
```
But is this a common use case / something users of sw-precache actually did?

R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #524 

This uses an environment variable, `TEST_BUNDLE`, to toggle between serving the `dev` and `prod` bundles in our test server. Other approaches, like trying to append a search parameter to the URL passed to `importScripts()`, seemed like it would make it harder to toggle between the bundle types without modifying code that's checked in.

This also fixes a few of the tests that previously relied on knowing the exact assertion name that caused an error to be throw, since that additional context wasn't available in the `prod` bundle. We're just using `assertion-failed` as the error name across all environments now.

I understand that I'll probably have to fix merge conflicts once #529 goes in, but I wanted to get this in for review and see if there were any major complaints.

I am not changing the CI or release process right now to automatically run the tests against the prod bundles as well. I don't feel great about doubling the time it takes for CI to run, but I can see the value of changing the release process to test against both the `dev` and `prod` bundles in a follow-up PR.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

I **think** this ends up accomplishing what we want for publishing, via `gulp lerna-publish`.

It does it by:
1. Running the publishing flow with git and npm integration turned off. This updates the `package.json` and `lerna.json` `version` fields for the modified packages in the local working directory, without committing anything.
2. Automatically updating the `main` and `module` fields of all packages to pick up any modified versions.
3. Re-running the publishing flow, this time with git and npm enabled, but with a forced version passed in, read from the current `lerna.json`. This will then commit everything to GitHub and push to npm.

Rather than sprinkling some of the build steps in `package.json`'s `scripts` and others in `gulp`, I moved everything `lerna`-related over to `gulp`. This required a light refactoring of the CI configuration.

This is all working for me without `--concurrency=1`, so I'm hoping we can move ahead with that and speed up `lerna` in general.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

This is based off the discussion in https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-helpers/issues/361#issuecomment-298640521

It swaps out the real [`error-stack-parser`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/error-stack-parser) module import for an import that has the same interface but is effectively a no-op. You lose a bit of context if an assertion fails without the real module, but our assertions are really meant to catch errors in a development environment, not after the service worker has been deployed.

This gets the production `sw-lib.min.js` bundle size down from 50249 bytes (14938 bytes gzip-ed) to 45450 bytes (13468 bytes gzip-ed).

I had to change a few of the tests that specifically examined the assertion failures to use the unminified bundle, but other than that, it's much less of a hack than it could have been.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

This is a substantial update to the build process, with the following changes:
- Moving from gulp wrappers on top of Rollup, babili, and others to directly using Rollup. This fixes #477, sourcemap generation.
- No longer including the async-to-generator transpilation, since async/await are natively supported in production Chrome and Firefox. We can turn this back on if we need.
- Changing the build process for `sw-offline-google-analytics` and `sw-background-sync-queue` to only generate unminimized `iife` bundles of the individual `.js` files that they need in order to run their tests, and to generate them all in parallel instead of sequentially.
- Adding in an `.npmignore` file to the directory that hosts the built tests for `sw-offline-google-analytics` and `sw-background-sync-queue` to ensure they're not published to `npm`.

As a result of these changes, we've saved a modest ~364 bytes on the gzip-ed size of `swlib.min.js`. But the built times should be much quicker across the board—I've seen improvements of around 10 seconds in `sw-lib`, and up to 40 seconds improvement for `sw-background-sync-queue` (which was really bad to begin with, due to a long sequential chain of bundled test code).

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Apologies for the large PR, but it touches a number of related topics that should probably be addressed all-or-nothing.

- It removes the `warmRuntimeCache()` method from `sw-lib`. The underlying `UnrevisionedCacheManager` class is left as-is in `sw-precaching`, with the understanding that if a developer explicitly wants to use it as part of their own piecemeal service worker without using `sw-lib`, they're free to do so. (Fixes #370)

- It renames `cacheRevisionedAssets()` to `precache()`, which hopefully emphasizes that it's the "correct" method to use for most cases. (Fixes #347, fixes #353)

- It adds a JSDoc comment and logs a message letting developers know about the automatic cache-first route for URLs that are in the precache list (Fixes #365)

- It exposes a `defaultRuntimeCacheName` getter in`sw-lib`, and includes an example of how that could be used in conjunction with the basic Cache Storage API to add/query the default cache. Developers who really need to manage this default cache can still do so via this approach, without `warmRuntimeCache()`. (Fixes #367)

It's possible that this PR closes some other closely related open issues, but these are the ones I could track down.

There's also an extra log message when there are URLs passed in to `precache()` that don't explicitly include revisioning information, letting developers know that they need to make sure the URL itself contains versioning info, or else they'll have a Bad Time.

R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #78 

This uses the logging layer implemented in `sw-cacheable-response` to let the developer know when there's a response that would otherwise be cached, but isn't due to the response code.

It changes the defaults for `NetworkFirst` and `StaleWhileRevalidate` to allow for opaque responses with status of `0` to be cached and used. The default for everything else is to require a response status of `200`.

One thing that it does not do is add any tests for the various behaviors, since `sw-runtime-caching` is currently untested 😨  I've got some WIP tests at https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-helpers/tree/runtime-caching-test and am fine with holding off on merging this PR until those tests are checked in, and then I'll modify this PR to include additional tests for response codes. Or you could just merge it sooner with the understanding that I'll cover the response code tests in the separate testing PR.

In any case, feel free to review for general feedback in the meantime.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #281 and fixes #237 

I *think* this accurately reflects what we agreed upon as a resolution to #281. I may be incorrect about what the takeaway from that was, so feel free to correct me and I'll correct the logic in this PR!

This change opens up `ExpressRoute` so that if you pass in a `path` value starting with `'https://'`, it will match cross-origin requests that go against the origin that you specify.

If you pass in a `path` value starting with `'/'` then it will continue to only match same-origin requests, which is similar to the old behavior.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #263 

This implements what's basically `sw-precache`'s `dynamicUrlToDependencies`, but with a name that @gauntface [agreed on](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-precache/issues/164#issuecomment-284524338). It also has support for both strings and globs as the value that uniquely determines the URL's contents, so there should be parity with @HenrikJoreteg's changes made in https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-precache/pull/262

I'm not 100% sure that I've made the changes in all the right places (do I need to touch something in `sw-cli` too?), as I'm not as familiar with this portion of the codebase. Feedback is appreciated.

R: @addyosmani @gauntface

This adds a new `NavigationRoute` class, fairly close to what's described in #169, which matches when `event.request.mode === 'navigate'` and the URL's pathname is in a whitelist (and not in a blacklist).

This lays the groundwork for App Shell routing. I think the next step would be to take this and add in some logic in `sw-lib` that made use of `NavigationRoute` coming after the route that matches precached assets, and allowed the developer to cleanly specify the URL that corresponds to their App Shell HTML.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Fixes #120 

This adds in support for a new lifecycle callback, `cacheWillMatch`, which gives behaviors a chance to intercept cache matches before they're returned to the handler, to check whether the matched value should be used.

It also modifies the `sw-cache-expiration` behavior to take advantage of this new callback, by examining the `Response` object that was retrieved from the cache, making sure that it's fresh, via a comparison of its `Date:` header to the configured `maxAgeSeconds` expiration.

This matches the behavior that was recently implemented in `sw-toolbox`: https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-toolbox/pull/206

R: @gauntface

Fixes #122

The major change was to move from storing the open IDB/Cache in a single variable to using a Map to store them with the cache name as a key. That ensures that even if `cacheDidUpdate` gets called multiple times with different `cacheName`s (for some reason...), the correct IDB/Cache instances will be used.

body: Related to https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-helpers/issues/78, this implements a behavior with the `cacheWillUpdate` callback. It effectively lets you pass in one or more statuses and one or more headers that are used to determine whether a response is cacheable or not. It also includes changes to the `RequestWrapper` in the runtime caching module so that it will automatically call `cacheWillUpdate` prior to adding a `Response` to the cache. If there are no `cacheWillUpdate` callbacks defined, `RequestWrapper` will just check the `.ok` property to determine whether a `Response` can be cached.

R: @addyosmani @gauntface
CC: @deanhume

This PR refactors much of the common build boilerplate into a helper method. That helper method also takes care of generating both minified and non-minified output, which fixes #31.

There are some packages that still require slightly different build setups, either due to their testing requirements or due to their legacy packaging requirements. In those cases I've switched over the part of the build that could be abstracted out into the general configuration, and left behind the things that needed to stay separate.

- Rejigged some of the code so that the RevisionedCacheManager is a little leaner and the code is easier to read.

- Changed {path: '', revision: ''} -> {url: '', revision: ''}

R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani 

This adds tests to cover the following scenarios:

- Duplicate entries are only cached onces
- Duplicate entries with the same path but different revisions throw an error
- 404 URLs aren't cached by default (Should this be extended to a range of status codes?
- CORs and Non-CORs requests are cached by default.

This is somewhat in prep for #78 where we'll introduce a way to override the default behavior. For now its response.ok || response.type === 'opaque' only.

body:
R: @addyosmani @gauntface

Here's an initial batch of JSDocs, for the `sw-broadcast-cache-update` project.

You can take a look at them rendered at https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-helpers/blob/jsdoc/projects/sw-broadcast-cache-update/README.md

It unfortunately feels like a pretty noisy page, and probably isn't the best format to share with developers, but that's just one possible rendering of the underlying JSDocs (via the [`documentation`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/documentation) library). I think @gauntface has alternative plans for how they'll get rendered in the future.

The one sore point that I ran into was that `documentation` forces the name `$0`for the  anonymous destructed object we're using as parameters in all the functions. That `$0` could be confusing, but it's [not currently possible to override](https://github.com/documentationjs/documentation/issues/270). Maybe we should consider post-processing the generated docs to convert `$0` to `parameters` or something?

body:
R: @jeffposnick @addyosmani @wibblymat @gauntface @ebidel _Description of what's changed/fixed._ ### This pull request adds two primary features: - **A new `hitFilter` configuration option**
This options allows developers to programmatically modify the hit params at runtime. This is useful to add/modify params when the `parameterOverrides` option alone isn't sufficient (e.g. when a value needs to be derived from another value). - **A new index files that exports the `offlineGoogleAnalytics` object without adding it to the `goog` scope**
In cases where you're using a module bundler to build your service worker, importing the built file can cause unnecessary duplication (especially if you're using `idb` elsewhere). Now users can npm install `sw-helpers` and in their code do the following: ``` js // Imports the module locally. const offlineGoogleAnalytics = require('sw-helpers/projects/sw-offline-google-analytics/src'); // Initializes the module via the local variable name. offlineGoogleAnalytics.initialize({...}); ``` _**Note:** `idb` needed to be added to `dependencies` instead of `devDependencies` to make this work._ ### It also updates the logic in two important ways: - **Replays are now more aggressively retried**
Since hits between 4-28 hours old may not be precessed, it's important to retry whenever possible. The old logic retried any time the service worker started up. The new logic adds an additional retry any time a successful hit was sent if the previous hit failed. - **Hits older than 2 days are discarded**
The previous logic only discarded old hits if they failed after being sent from the service worker. The new logic inspects the age of the hit prior to all replay attempts and only replays hits less than 48 hours old.

Fixes #22

This updates the project to use the 0.1.1 release of `sw-testing-helpers` along with the new `selenium-assistant` dependency.

_Unforunately_, this still leads to broken tests with Firefox. While we are now using the Marionette driver, which works with Firefox 48+, the combination of Marionette + `selenium-webdriver` 2.53 makes it impossible to set the async script timeout. So the Travis CI tests are still failing.

https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-testing-helpers/issues/48 tracks updating `sw-testing-helpers` to use `selenenium-webdriver` 3.0 betas, which fixes the issue with timeouts.

body:
R: @addyosmani @wibblymat @gauntface

Fixes #28 

This PR accomplishes two things in `sw-appcache-behavior`:
- It uses the new shared top-level libraries, `idb-helper.js`, `log.js`, and `scope.js`.
- Using `scope.js`, it changes the exposed interface from `goog.legacyAppCacheBehavior` to `goog.appCacheBehavior.fetch`, to match what we're doing with namespaces in `sw-offline-google-analytics`.

This is a breaking change, but given that it's a move from v0.0.4 to v0.0.5, I believe it's in keeping with semver best practices around releases less than v0.1.0.

R: @addyosmani @wibblymat @gauntface
CC: @philipwalton @igrigorik 

Fixes #8 #19 

This adds the code for a new `sw-offline-google-analytics` project, along with a quick demo and tests. The underlying code is conceptually similar to what's been deployed elsewhere as part of larger projects (like IOWA), and I've gotten some feedback on it from @igrigorik and @philipwalton in the past.

One of the larger changes to that existing codebase was to refactor the imported code into a couple of different modules that handle IndexedDB interactions. I then wrote some tests against those modules. Hopefully this makes up to some extent for not being able to put together a meaningful end-to-end automated test that simulates a lack of network connectivity.

body:
R: @jakearchibald @addyosmani @wibblymat @gauntface

Fixes #18 

This code checks the age of the response from the AppCache manifest request, and if it's older than 24 hours, makes another request using `cache: reload` to (ideally) bypass the cache, to work around http://alistapart.com/article/application-cache-is-a-douchebag#section6

I'm using `cache: reload` here, which unfortunately isn't universally supported in browsers right now. The alternative would be to append cache-busting URL parameters to the request, but I feel like it's in keeping with the spirit of this library to use the primitives provided by the platform. This is also an additional nice-to-have feature beyond the core functionality of the library, so if `cache: reload` doesn't have an effect, we're no worse off than we were.
